required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Best Cutoff Value of Lactate Concentration in Vaginal Fluid to Predict Time of Spontaneous Onset of Labor in PPROM
clinical_study.official_title: Best Cutoff Value of Lactate Concentration in Vaginal Fluid to Predict Time of Spontaneous Onset of Labor in PPROM

brief_summary.textblock: The present study is aimed to assess whether lactate determination in vaginal fluid is associated with and can predict onset of labor for women with suspected preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROMs).

primary_outcome.measure: Time from examination to spontaneous onset of labor
primary_outcome.description: Time from examination to spontaneous onset of labor < or > 48 hours according to concentration of lactate in vaginal fluid

clinical_study.condition: Aim is to Investigate Association Between Lactate Concentration in Vaginal Fluid and Time of Spontaneous Onset of Labor in PPROM

study_pop.textblock: This study will be conducted on 42 healthy pregnant with preterm PROM women they will be investigated for lactate concentration in vaginal fluid and observed for latency period till onset of spontaneous labor

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 25-35 years old
- BMI 25-30
- Singleton pregnancy in presentation with a history of suspected PPROM
- A live fetus with gestational age between 26+0 weeks and 34+0 weeks
Exclusion Criteria:
- Abruption placenta
- Medical disorders and hypertensive disorders of pregnancy
- Intrauterine fetal death
- Known or suspected fetal anomalies
- Signs of infection (Fever, increase total leucocytic count)
- Multiple pregnancy.
- Regular uterine contractions.
- History of cervical insufficiency

responsible_party.investigator_title: Best Cutoff value of lactate concentration in vaginal fluid to predict time of spontaneous onset of labor in PPROM
